data.body: Using our good old `--webkit-mask` trick.

data.title: Expose status bar debugging and no-folder foreground colors.
data.body: Just being able to change the foreground color may not be enough in cases where the background color is radically different.

data.title: Support glob pattern "**/!(*.min).js" for file watchers
data.body:
I am trying to write an extension, and I am wondering how I can take this pattern:

```js
glob(vscode.workspace.rootPath + '/**/!(*.min).js', (err, files) => {
    console.log(files);
})
```
And use it here:
```js
let watcher = vscode.workspace.createFileSystemWatcher('**/!(*.min).js', true, false, true);
```

It seems as if the `!(*.min)` is not supported. It would be nice if either:

**A** `!()` was supported
OR
**B** There is another parameter for ignoring files similar to `vscode.workspace.findFiles()`

data.title: [Solved] Activating extension vscode.git failed
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 17.04
- Git Version ~~2.11.0~~ > ~~2.13.0~~ > 2.12.2

There was a `git-man` update in the Software Updates. Maybe that caused it? Currently figuring out how to revert an update.

Error Message:
[Extension Host] Activating extension `vscode.git` failed:  Invalid or unexpected token

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19337229/26292102/f016c616-3ee5-11e7-9f72-c2bd09d80e56.png)

Update 1:
Not sure if this helps but I found the package in the update. `git-man:amd64 (1:2.11.0-2, 1:2.11.0-2ubuntu0.1)` There was also an update to git `git:amd64 (1:2.11.0-2, 1:2.11.0-2ubuntu0.1)`

Update 2:
Updated git to version 2.13.0 and still not working.

Update 3:
Re-installed VS Code and working now. I will try to update git to 2.13.0 later

Pending Possible Solutions:
1. Update git to version 2.13.0 (Fail)
2. Downgrade git to version 2.12.2 Same as my colleague (Fail)
3. Re-install VS Code **(Success)**

data.title: Go to Definiton does not work in JavaScript namespace
Escape for `keepEditor` and `hideInterfaceOverview`
data.body:
I want to keep my tab active (not closing when switch to another file, `keepEditor` command) with escape and I want to hide hints (`hideInterfaceOverview`) with the same button. You know, like in sublime.

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: `Ubuntu 16.04` `Mac El Capitan` (actually, whatever)

Steps to Reproduce:

```
  {
    "key": "escape",
    "command": "workbench.action.keepEditor",
    "when": "!interfaceOverviewVisible"
  },
  {
    "key": "escape",
    "command": "workbench.action.hideInterfaceOverview",
    "when": "interfaceOverviewVisible"
  },
```

In some reason it's working only for `keepEditor` command. Hints not closing, `hideInterfaceOverview` not working with this condition.

data.title: Arrow keys not working when using R in a VSCode terminal

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

I seem to have stumbled into a key binding issue when running R under a VSCode terminal. The keys work just fine when R.exe is used under a basic Windows 10 terminal or RStudio. Under a VSCode terminal, they do nothing, not even the weird characters that show up when the key strokes are not mapped correctly (typically correct with an .inputrc file).

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Download and install R from https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/base/R-3.4.0-win.exe
2. Open a terminal in VSCode
3. Run "C:\Program Files\R\R-3.4.0\bin\x64\R.exe"
4. Attempt using the tab, left, right, up or down arrow keys

I have confirmed that the keys work when using R under a cmd.exe terminal. Any help that you can provide is helpful.

Thanks for all the great work!

data.title: Support for adding to the completion list rather than replacing it.
data.body:
I do understand that by design Visual Studio Code gives only [one completion provider](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4791) the ability to provide completions. But there are cases when adding to the completion list would be very helpful.

I am looking for a solution to https://github.com/atishay/vscode-allautocomplete/issues/3 . Please provide suggestions of you have any that can remove the requirement of this feature request.

data.title: Terminate all tasks

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 17.04

Steps to Reproduce:

I have multiple tasks running, One Sass and one TypeScript, I would like to be able to end all tasks with one keyboard shortcut. I currently have to end each task separately, so it would be nice to have something that will end all tasks.

Here is what I have for tasks:

```json
{
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "showOutput": "always",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "isBuildCommand": true,
            "taskName": "Build",
            "dependsOn": [
                "Build Sass",
                "Build TypeScript"
            ]
        },
        {
            "taskName": "Build Sass",
            "command": "node-sass",
            "args": [
                "-w",
                "./src/sass/main.scss",
                "./public/assets/css/prefab.css",
                "--output-style",
                "compressed"
            ]
        },
        {
            "taskName": "Build TypeScript",
            "command": "tsc",
            "problemMatcher": "$tsc-watch",
            "args": [
                "-w",
                "-p",
                "./src/typescript"
            ]
        }
    ]
}
```

data.title: Python VENV environments not recognized
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 version 1703 (OS Build 15063.296)
- Extensions installed: Python v0.6.4

VS Code does not appear to recognise the structure of Python virtual environments, requiring the code to be run outside of VS, from a terminal window.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a Python `venv` environment (`python -m venv foldername`)
2. Install 3rd party modules to `venv` (`Scripts\activate.bat`, `pip install -r requirements.txt`).
3. Note listed Problems in VS Code include numerous "E0401:Unable to import 'module'" pertaining to the installed (and imported) modules from step 2.

data.body: Fixes #26730

data.title: Inconsistent undo/redo behavior in Ctrl-F field

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Press Ctrl-F
2. Type something into the field
3. Select some text in the file being edited
4. Press Ctrl-F again
5. Try to undo/redo using keyboard shortcuts

Characters will be deleted and added almost at random, based on the field's state before the contents were replaced in step 4. This seems to be because the undo/redo history stores characters being entered and deleted, but the replacement of the entire field contents *is not stored* on the field's history stack. If it were, an undo would simply revert the Ctrl-F field to its earlier state.

Other fields may have the same problem - the basic issue here is that an operation isn't being pushed to the history stack.

data.title: column mode edit is wrong
data.body:
It's a well known how column mode edit works. Try VS or even Notepad++, it's always alt+shift+cursor to make multiline selection in column mode, or if you are using mouse it's alt+mouse down (and with a bit different behavior alt+shift+mouse click).

This is something that I personally use very often and won't ever use editor that cannot do this properly with these exact shortcuts. Can this be configured to work properly instead of all these move up/down lines that are now used by alt+up/down shortcut?

The only thing that seems the be working the same in vscode is alt+shift+mouse click or moving mouse while holding left button down.

Column mode edit/selection isn't some kind of random set of shortcuts, but has clear logic (in VS or Notepad++ or any other editor that does the same), in short the logic is simple: just like regular selection works with mouse or cursor navigation column mode works **exactly the same** the only difference is that alt is needed to change line-mode to column-mode. Or to put it in other words: holding shift enables selection mode, selection mode is switched to column-mode if alt is pressed also.

There was never Ctrl involved, why would you do that kind of mess?!

data.title: Ctrl+s saves/overwrites the wrong content to the wrong file - Can cause lost work

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.12.2 (19222cdc84ce72202478ba1cec5cb557b71163de, 2017-05-10T13:20:36.315Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.3|
|intellij-idea-keybindings|k--kato|0.2.10|
|python|tht13|0.2.3|;


---

I've lost my work twice in a few days because of this, so I hope this is addressed quickly if it turns out it's not just me. The potential bug is best explained by describing steps to reproduce.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file in a separate VSCode window, make some changes then save changes
2. Open a new file (Ctrl+N) that opens in a new tab in the same VSCode window
3. Make changes to the new unsaved and untitled file
4. Without saving the new file, go back to original file, make more changes
5. Save the changes with Ctrl+S

Unexpectedly, the "Save as..." window appears. When this happened to me the second time I wondered if I had the wrong file/tab open when pressing Ctrl+S, but I could see that I had the correct tab open/selected behind the "Save as..." window.

6. There's no reason to rename the file, so save it with the same path/name as before

A dialog asking to confirm overwriting the existing file appears.

7. Confirm overwriting.


Upon confirming, a few things happen:

- The open/selected tab disappears
- The previously unsaved file is now displayed
- The unsaved file has now been saved with whatever specified in the "Save as..." window
- If the same path/name as the original file was specified, the original file has now been overwritten
- Ctrl+Z history from the original file has been wiped, removing the last hope for retrieving the lost file contents

data.title: Find and replace appears still broken in 1.12.2 depending on UI workflow
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.12
- OS Version: osx 10.12.4

1. In a JS file, select some code on 1 line.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/174335/26285262/4bf5d282-3e1a-11e7-96c8-29bbc0da5cd7.png)  
2. from menu: Edit | Replace
3. In the Find dialog, select the Find textbox that has the code you've highlighted  
4. type the text of something in the line you've highlighted- in the attached image, it would be "minute". For example, imagine you wanted to replace "minute" with "hour" in the highlighted code. Notice that "minute" is highlighted in the editor.
5. In the dialog, click the "Find in selection" button. Notice that only the -first- instance of what you're finding is now selected in the editor. But you didn't want the -first- replaced, you wanted them all.
6. So select the line again in the editor 
7. click Replace All and notice that only the -first- instance of what you're trying to replace is replaced, and then you get a "No Results" found message.  
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/174335/26285274/830060bc-3e1a-11e7-822e-74ba652fdf13.png)
  
  
There's a workaround, but since vsC (unfortunately) automatically puts what you've highlighted in to the Find textbox, this is the more normal workflow.

This same basic problem existed in VStudio several versions once the F/R functionality automatically selected your highlights...



https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5239

data.title: Terminal List Dropdown shows blank for the first time

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows Insider Build 16199

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch VSCode.
2. Press **Ctrl + `** to view Terminal.
3. Press on the **+** button next to the Terminal list dropdown for New Terminal (_You may press it several times_). New Terminal(s) shows up.
4. Press on the down arrow in the Terminal list dropdown. 
    **Expected Result** : The dropdown list should display list of Terminals.
    **Actual Result** : The dropdown list is blank. (_Although the height of the dropdown list is proportional to the number of Terminals_) 
5. Click elsewhere to dismiss the dropdown list.
6. Press on the down arrow in the Terminal list dropdown again.
7. The drop down list **now** shows the list of Terminals properly.

data.title: markdown.showpreview failed when file is located on a NAS (WD MyCloud and others)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Prof. 1703

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a file like test.md with some markdown and store at 
a) on your computer ( i.e. c:\tmp) and 
b) on a Public Network path (i.e. \\NAS-3TB-II\Public)
2. Open in VS Code and try to open the preview with Ctrl-Shift-V
a) will work fine 
b) will fail

Reading and saving the file works with both locations, only preview fails.

On Ubuntu Gnome (16.04)/Virtualbox  it works fine on both locations.

data.title: Special input causes vscode to hang
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new plain text file, paste "soooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo" into the first line.
2. Manually type "oooooooooooooooooooo" in the second line. The editor will hang when you are typing.

It seems like there are too many calls of function `findAllMatches`.
